content: I've corrected the typo ("thieves" originally spelled as "thiefs") and added full-stops to the steps.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting problem, well presented!
I'm wondering if this should be set to easy instead of medium difficulty?

The formatting makes it a bit bad readable and I don't know if the wiki article is really necessary but I really enjoyed this one :)
Also the use of hex came a bit unexpected.

It's an entertaining story, but make sure the encoding process is clear instead of just linking to Wikipedia.  In particular you never mentioned the second encoding step: turning characters into hex digits.

Because it’s not part of the cipher.
But, in order to use random (non printable) bytes in CG inputs we have to use another encoding. Like hex or Base64 for example.

I chose hex because one can apply XOR more easily. The bitwise XOR works fine, the hex one is just a 4-time-faster shortcut

would it be more understandable and readable if I replace the hex strings by byte code arrays ?
(honestly, it does not cost anything to me to replace this...)

The wiki article is just here to introduce the 'unbreakable one time pad' - otherwise some people might not understand why the key has to be as long as the message.

Actually, this is a real crypto technique (called Diffie-Hellman) to use a commutative cipher to get a common private key from both sides without having to exchange it.
The goal here is to prove that even robust ciphers and techniques can lead to huge security flaws when misused.

Diffie-Hellman indeed relies on commutativity but is more of a one-pass protocol to agree on a secret key (not send a message). The protocol you describe is Shamir's three-pass protocol https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-pass_protocol but using XOR (which is indeed a bad idea) instead of something more reliable such as RSA with the same modulus.

That’s true. But (true story) I found once a piece of code in a product where a private key was generated on both sides using DH and XORs.
That’s where this problem idea comes from.
And that’s why I mentioned DH instead of 3-pass (note that the test cases are about to exchange a private key between Alice and Bob ^^)
Saying "hex" in the input section is far from enough. It's many times ambiguous, for a start.

Fair enough. Also, base on the initial description, the hex form of the message should be a valid answer (but obviously isn’t...)

I updated the description with a description of hexadecimal format.
